replies.name: D
replies.comment info:
@Taylor Belz 
The significant price increases in household paper products (31-32%) are due to rising raw material costs such as wood, supply chain shortages, labour shortages, and increased demand, all due to COVID-19. Because the gap between prices continues to increase with and without accounting for size suggest shrinkflation, where products get smaller while prices remain high. Similarly, price hikes in things like snacks and candy is likely due to the aforementioned factors, with price hikes occurring in materials like sugar, cocoa, and grain.

name: Moderator Tonya
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received: “A Closer Look at the Price and Size of Consumer Items!” by Kemoura from Perth Amboy High School in New Jersey, “How Does Size Influence Price?" Trey of Elk Rapids High School in Mich. , “Shrinkage Increases Inflation” by GCA in SoCal, and four headlines from California Polytechnic State University, San Luis Obispo:  “How Hidden Changes in Product Size Impact Your Wallet” by Kylie; “Size Matters: Unpacking Grocery Store Price Hikes” by Isabelle; "Secret Shrinkage: Tracking Hidden Risings in Grocery Bills" by Hailey and "’Shrink-flation’: Less Product for Your Dollar" by Alexander.
 
Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article that included this graph, a summary of the article, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graphs and where you can find them in the graphs.
 
The next graph will be released by Friday, April 19 with live-moderation two-weeks later on Wednesday, May 1.  The topic is still to be determined.
 
Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who is missing the half-quart from the half-gallon of ice cream, and Tonya Adkins of Charlotte, N.C., who recently had a related conversation regarding Reece’s Cups!

The graph shows the price of items in 2019 and 2023, comparing their prices when accounting for changes in size and not accounting for it. This graph displays the change in price of products such as coffee, house cleaning products, snacks, candy/chewing gum, and household paper products from January 2019 to October 2023. I notice that the price of every product on this graph has gone up more than 20% since 2019 with or without accounting for weight. I can conclude this is likely due to rising inflation. name: Justin Mai
comment info: The graph are results from January 2019 to October 2023, and the choices they picked for the products were products such that every single American could have bought at least one of these items during that time. Paper products have the greatest price increase when accounting for size. "Accounting for size" adjusts the price change to reflect any changes in the quantity or size of the product, which is leading to an even higher price per dollar value than from years past. In every category, the price increase is more significant when size is accounted for, what most call "shrinkflation." I wonder what caused the increase in prices and whether it was due to inflation, increased production costs or just pure greed. I wonder how these price changes compare to the overall rate of inflation and whether people's salaries increased at the same rate (probably not). I also wonder why paper products have the greatest price increase in general, maybe due to the toilet paper crisis during COVID.  The increase in everyday products like snacks and household items have caused strain in my families budgets since I remember that we always used to have way more food at home after going to the grocery store, but now we only wait for sales and buy as little as we can. The difference in price when size is accounted for means that we are paying more for less, which lead to us buying more off brand items instead to help combat shrinkflation. Headline: The Silent Squeeze of Shrinkflation Hits Home

name: Dechen Drongpa
comment info:
I noticed that the graph is a comparison of price changes for various consumer goods from January 2019 to October 2023, specifically for coffee, household cleaning products, snacks, candy and chewing gum, and household paper products. It compares the price changes when not accounting for size and when accounting for size. The prices for all the items seems to have increased over the period. This suggests that there may have been a reduction in the size of the products, a phenomenon known as shrinkflation. I wonder about the changes in different rates of price increase between the goods. It would be interesting to investigate the factors contributing. There are a lot of impacts on the community and me as price increases in everyday consumer goods have a significant impact on budgets, especially when wages do not increase together with inflation. The higher rates of increase when accounting for size can show how the consumers might be getting less value for their money over time, which makes it harder to buy most goods. For communities, this can lead to disproportionately affect lower-income households even more severely as they do not have the luxury of disposable income.

Catchy headline:
"Feeling Robbed?"

replies.comment info:
HI, @Dechen Drongpa --

You’ve got the story of the graph.  But, does your headline tell viewers what the graph is about and entice them to read the story?

name: Miguel
comment info: Prices have increased by at least 20 percent across the five products. Whether these trends will continue at the same rates or whether it was partially a byproduct of the pandemic. It’s concerning how much the prices of such products have increased after accounting for the size of the products. The prices of five popular grocery items could increase to a point until they are unattainable for the general population. Thus a fitting title would be "Expensive Essentials: Shrinkflation's Effects".

replies.name: S
replies.comment info: @Miguel Why do you think that some products had a greater price increase than others?

name: Alex Tran
comment info: The first thing I noticed was how much each product’s price change increased when accounting for quantity and size, nodding to how companies are increasing prices because of inflation but also decreasing the quantity/volume of products to reach desirable profit margins. Given that consumers purchase these products very often, it is probably difficult to notice subtle changes in quantity especially over long periods. I wonder whether this trend applies to all other consumer items since there could be other items that may not be as different when, for example, adjusting for size or increasing prices due to inflation. I also wonder how household paper products' largest change in price relates to COVID-19 when many households stocked up on toilet paper to the point where stores ran out of paper products. I wonder if these household paper product companies noticed how crucial their products are to consumers and decided to increase profit margins even greater than they were before. This relates to me both as a consumer and a statistician because, in an economy already struggling with inflation, shrinkflation, COVID-19 recovery, etc., it is difficult to navigate what products are worth my time and money. To see these companies increasing their profit margins makes me question whether they have their consumers’ best interests in mind or solely want to exploit us for money. A catchy headline could be “Pockets Feeling Lighter? Higher Prices and Lesser Quantities Could Explain Why.”

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Alex Tran --

You got it!  Most students who responded did not see the significance of adjusting prices for size.  How would you design the graph to more clearly show the effect of size on prices?

name: Kaatje Matthews
comment info:
The first thing I noticed is the scale of the x-axis. First of all, since the x-axis does not start at 0, the price increase of coffee seems to be small in comparison to the others, even though a 20% increase is still fairly large. Additionally, since the x-axis is based on percentage increases instead of actual dollar increases, it standardizes the scale so it is easier to compare the 5 items. However, this means we do not know how the dollars increased, so it can be difficult to interpret the actual difference in pricing. Since the item categories are very general, I wonder what items are included in each category, and how the prices are calculated across all those items. This information is very relevant to everyone in my community because we all went through the pandemic, so to see how most of the products being used on a daily basis have increased significantly from before coronavirus hit the US is quite important to us all. Also, as a college student, knowing how much more these items are costing motivates me to save more and reduce my spending on unnecessary items.
Title:  “Less Costs More: How Shrinkflation is Affecting Essentials Post-Pandemic”

The spread of the size variability also seems fairly consistent between coffee, household cleaning products, and candy and chewing gum, being at about a difference of 2-3%. name: Coleton Enyart
comment info: The post-COVID surge in paper product prices seems like a twist in the narrative of economic recovery. One would assume that with the return of normalcy, prices would stabilize or even decrease. However, the opposite seems to be true for paper products. Perhaps the increased demand for these items during the pandemic, coupled with disruptions in the global supply chain, created a ripple effect that's still being felt. It's odd to witness how a crisis that initially drove panic-buying and shortages has now left a lasting impact on something as mundane as the cost of paper goods. This unexpected phenomenon underscores the intricate interplay between consumer behavior, market dynamics, and unforeseen consequences in our interconnected world.

name: Daniel
comment info:
I noticed that every single grocery item included in this plot not only saw a change in price between January 2019 and October 2023 but increased in price. The most noticeable change for me was the increase in price when accounting for the size of the item. For example, without focusing on the size of household paper products, we see that the price increased by around 23 to 24%. However, once we included its size, it increased by around 26%.
	I wonder what the main reason is for these specific items’ increase in price over the years, and if the pandemic had anything to do with it considering that this graph starts a few months before quarantine. Additionally, I remember toilet paper being out of stock in many stores during quarantine; this would explain why household paper products seem to have an especially large increase in price than others, allowing me to make this conclusion. 
	This can pose a concern for my community and me in that increases in necessities, such as cleaning and paper products, contribute to people not having basic needs met. If we continue seeing these types of trends, my community and I can see many basic household items that will be out of the range of our pockets.
Catchy headline: “The Difference Between Needs and Wants: Are basic necessities basically becoming luxuries?”

name: Deven
comment info:
When looking at the graph I notice that for every one of the five popular grocery store items, when size is accounted for the change in price for all items goes up by a higher percentage. I also notice that this graph includes pre, mid, and post pandemic dates which would be an influence in the price fluctuations. I think that the grocery stores have found that because these are such staple household items, they can easily raise prices and cover that with size without the consumers noticing.

I wonder if the reason in the increase is due to inflation. I know these past few years inflation rates have been at an all time high and that could definitely be a reason for the price increase. I also am wondering if maybe the demand of COVID and the fact that during the pandemic most of these items were hard to come by, especially paper products, has allowed grocery stores to raise their prices without the consequence of less people buying them. And the fact that they were able to raise the prices has given them confidence to constantly keep increasing the prices of these items.

This directly applies to my community of being a student in college who does not have a full time job nor steady income. These items are ones that I know both me and many of my peers purchase almost weekly. The increase in prices makes these essential items less affordable but because of the constant demand, prices will not drop and we are forced to pay it.

Title:"Cheap Necessities: Is that so hard?"

name: Kylie Scharf
comment info:
I notice that accounting for the change in size when considering the percent change in price for all 5 grocery items makes the change more significant. The companies likely try to influence consumers to believe the price changes are not very much by not accounting for the accompanying change in size. In reality, this change in size can have a substantial effect on the value consumers are receiving for their money. 

I wonder the extent to which the public is aware of these tactics. Are most consumers cognizant of the relationship between price changes and accompanying changes in product size? I know that for me, I feel deceived after looking at this graph. I had not considered the effect of the change in size on the true change in the price of a product. I wonder if others feel similarly or if they already knew about this and accepted it. 

In my community, I believe this discussion could spark a range of insights and reflections. Discussions within the community could also delve into potential solutions or responses to these practices. Members might brainstorm ideas for promoting greater transparency in pricing or advocating for stronger consumer protections. 

Headline idea: How Hidden Changes in Product Size Impact Your Wallet
